newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Focus - Luxembourg's Arbed falls into loss.
newsitem.headline: Focus - Luxembourg's Arbed falls into loss.

text.p: Luxembourg-based steel group Arbed said on Wednesday it tumbled into loss in 1996 after a sharp fall in steel prices that only began to recover at the end of the year.

Arbed said that because of a shrinking economy, European steel production had fallen sharply in 1996. At the same time clients' destocking and a large drop in spending on investments had contributed to a tumble in steel prices.
"It was not until the last months of 1996 that the trend turned around under the influence of a pick up in demand accompanied by a selective increase in prices," Arbed said in a statement.
"This tendency has been confirmed in the first quarter of 1997," it added.
The steel maker said a loss in long products had not been compensated for by positive results in the group's other sectors.

Arbed made a group loss of 1.21 billion Luxembourg francs ($34.9 million) after a 3.66 group net profit in 1995. It announced a 1996 consolidated net loss of 928 million versus a 6.615 billion profit.
Turnover fell 9.7 percent - or 4.6 percent on a comparable consolidation basis - to 232.23 billion francs.
Gross operating profit dropped 37 percent to 19.48 and cashflow more than halved to 10.50 billion.

Arbed said in a statement it had substantially reduced net financial charges in 1996 of 6.7 billion francs, an exceptional loss of 0.7 billion and taxes of 840 million. It gave no comparative figures.
After large investments net financial debt rose to 81.6 billion from 75.9 billion at the end of 1995.
Arbed's production of iron ore, pellets and pellet feed held steady at 21.83 million tonnes, and crude steel output climbed 2.3 percent to 11.77 million tonnes.
Rolled steel production rose 2.5 percent to 10.91 million tonnes. This included 6.49 million tonnes of flat steel, a rise of 5.5 percent, and 3.98 million of long steel, a fall of 1.5 percent.
Arbed's parent company profit fell 44 percent to 767 million francs. ($ = 34.72 Luxembourg Francs)
